did.unittitle: Xavier University Capital Gifts Campaigns collection
did.abstract: This is a collection of documents relating to the various capital gifts campaigns conducted by Xavier University. It encompasses the St. Xavier Diamond Jubilee Fund (1915-1920) through the To See Great Wonders campaign (2006-2011).

bioghist.head: History of Xavier University Capital Gifts Campaigns
bioghist.p: Xavier University has conducted various capital gifts campaigns throughout its history. This collection reflects those campaigns initiated in the Twentieth Century and going forward. Capital gifts campaigns are differentiated from the annual fund raising activities also conducted by the university.

Capital gifts campaigns for the time period encompassing this collection were: 1. Diamond Jubilee (1915), for the building of Alumni Hall; 2. Jesuit Centennial Fund (1940) that celebrated the 400th anniversary of the founding of the Society of Jesus, and the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the Jesuits in Cincinnati. Its purpose was to raise money for academic scholarships, for endowed scholarships, for endowed professorial chairs, and to eliminate university debt; 3. Xavier University Fund and Good Will Campaign (1945), for endowments and building projects; 4. Long Range Development Program (1956) that celebrated the 125th anniversary of the establishment of the Athenaeum, for scholarships, fellowships, and building construction; 5. Xavier University Advancement Fund (1972); 6. Sesquicentennial Fund celebrating the 150th anniversary of the establishment of the Athenaeum, for a new College of Business Administration building and endowments; 7. Cornerstone Campaign (1987), for scholarships, endowments, and building activities, including new science facilities; 8. Century Campaign (1996), for endowments, building renovations, and the building of a convocation center (later named the Cintas Center); 9. To See Great Wonders(2006), for the construction of the Hoff Academic Quadrangle, other construction projects, endowments and to increase the annual fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection includes correspondence, brochures, reports and other materials relating to the various capital gifts campaigns conducted by Xavier University (formerly St. Xavier College) from 1915 to the early 21st Century.

arrangement.head: Statement of Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged by folder chronologically by the period of the individual capital gifts campaign.

did.unittitle: St. Xavier Diamond Jubilee Fund

scopecontent.p: This folder contains a 1915 appeal to Xavier alumnae and friends to support the campaign.

relatedmaterial.p: For further information concerning this campaign, see XUA-53 Xavier University Master Building Plans collection.

bioghist.p: The St. Xavier Diamond Jubilee Fund (1915-1920) was initiated in celebration of the 75th anniversary of the arrival of the Jesuits at St. Xavier College in 1840. It was St. Xavier College's first public appeal for financial support. The campaign was sponsored by the St. Xavier Diamond Jubilee Fund Committee with a goal of $75,000.00. The purpose of the campaign included funding for new buildings for the Avondale campus. The Fund paid the major portion of the cost of Alumni Science Hall (later renamed Edgecliff Hall). Francis Heiermann, S.J. was the president of St. Xavier College at this time.

did.unittitle: Jesuit Centennial Fund (1940) Preparatory and Introductory Records

scopecontent.p: This folder contains a campaign publicity brochure.

bioghist.p: The Jesuit Centennial Fund celebrated the 400th anniversary of the founding of the Society of Jesus (1540) and the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the Jesuits in Cincinnati (1840). This fund was sponsored by the Jesuit Centennial Fund Committee. The committee's honorary chair was John T. McNicholas, the Archbishop of Cincinnati. The general chair was Charles F. Williams.
The purpose of the campaign was to raise money for academic scholarships, for endowed scholarships, for endowed professorial chairs and to eliminate university debt.
Celestin Steiner, S.J. was the president of Xavier University at this time.

Xavier University Fund and Good Will Campaign (1945-1952)

scopecontent.p: This folder contains campaign related correspondence and published materials.

bioghist.p: The purpose of the Xavier University Fund and Good Will Campaign was to raise $ 450,000.00 for the Endowment Fund and $ 550,000.00 for building projects. Proposed buildings included an assembly hall, an additional classroom, and dormitory rooms for out of town students. The campaign was sponsored by the Citizens' Committee, Richard E. LeBlond chair. Celestin Steiner, S.J. was the president of Xavier at this time.

did.unittitle: Long Range Development Program for Xavier University (1956-1957)

scopecontent.p: This folder contains published campaign materials.

relatedmaterial.p: For further information and pictures concerning this campaign, see archival collection XUA-53 Master Buildings Plans collection.

bioghist.p: The Long Range Development Program for Xavier University was initiated in celebration of the 125th anniversary of the establishment of the Athenaeum (1831), the forerunner of St. Xavier College and Xavier University. The purpose of the campaign was to financially support additional faculty, scholarships, and building construction.

did.unittitle: Xavier University Advancement Fund (1972-1977)

scopecontent.p: This folder contains correspondence and memos.

relatedmaterial.p: See Xavier Archives collection XUA-18, Planning and Development Committee records for preparatory materials that place the Xavier University Advancement Fund effort in context.

bioghist.p: The goal of the Xavier University Advancement Fund was to raise 30 million dollars over a ten year period. The campaign actually raised a total of $ 8,600,000.00. A Planning and Development Committee was established by Xavier president Paul O'Connor, S.J. in 1968 to prepare for this campaign (see Xavier archives collection XUA-18, Planning and Development Committee records). The campaign was phased out in 1976.

bioghist.p: The Sesquicentennial Campaign was conducted in celebration of the 150th anniversary of the establishment of the Athenaeum (1831), the forerunner of St. Xavier College and Xavier University. The purposes of the campaign were to build a new College of Business Administration building and to further fund endowments for the library, scholarships, faculty development, facilities renovation and instructional equipment. The campaign raised $8,389,683.00. Robert W. Mulligan, S.J. was president of the university at that time.

bioghist.p: The Cornerstone Campaign had as its purpose to raise funds to create endowed scholarships, endowed professorial chairs, and endowed faculty development. It also sought to enhance the university's science facilities by new construction and renovation. The campaign raised nearly 31.5 million dollars. Albert DiUlio, S.J. was president of the university at that time.

did.unittitle: Century Campaign (1996-2001)

scopecontent.p: This folder contains: 1. Various program leaflets relating to public events regarding the campaign; 2. Issues of Milestones (the campaign newsletter); 3. Information concerning a Century Campaign history video.

relatedmaterial.p: For documents and records concerning the strategic plan, XU 2000, which accompanied this campaign, consult the collection XUA-57, Xavier University Long Range Strategic Planning collection. For documents concerning the construction of the new buildings during this time, consult XUA-53, Xavier University Master Building Plans collection. For information on the Gallagher Student Center and the Cintas Center see also XUA-54, Xavier University Campus Buildings and Properties collection.

bioghist.p: The Century Campaign was meant to prepare Xavier University for its entrance into the Twenty-First Century. The campaign raised over 125 million dollars. James Hoff, S.J. was president of the university at that time. The purposes of the campaign were numerous, including the creation of endowed scholarships and professorships, the creation of an endowment for faculty development, the renovation of Hinkle, Schmidt and Alumni Science Halls, the renovation of the Academic Mall and Residential Mall, the creation of the Xavier Green; the renovation of the University Student Center, and the construction of a Convocation Center (later known as the Cintas Center).

did.unittitle: To See Great Wonders Campaign (2006-2011)

scopecontent.p: This folder contains campaign publicity literature, a campaign key ring, and other items related to the campaign.

relatedmaterial.p: For documents and records concerning the strategic planning which accompanied this campaign, consult XUA-57, Xavier University Long Range Strategic Planning collection. For documents and records concerning the construction of new buildings during this time, consult XUA-53, Xavier University Master Building Plans collection. For information on Fenwick Place see XUA-54, Xavier University Campus Buildings and Properties collection.

bioghist.p: To See Great Wonders: the Campaign for Xavier (2006-2001) had multiple purposes: to construct/remodel the Hoff Academic Quadrangle (the Conaton Learning Center, Smith Hall, renovate McDonald Library and renovate Alter Hall); to construct the new Campus Gateway at St. Francis Xavier Way and Dana Avenue; to construct the Fenwick Place Residence and Dining Complex; to create the Campus Square; to increase the university endowment; and to increase the annual fund. The campaign raised 201 million dollars. Michael J. Graham, S.J. was the president of the university at that time.
